questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient experiencing respiratory distress?
options: Encouraging deep breathing and coughing exercises
Administering a sedative to promote relaxation
Placing the patient in a supine position
Administering a bronchodilator without assessing lung sounds
questions.answer: Encouraging deep breathing and coughing exercises
questions.explanation: Encouraging deep breathing and coughing exercises is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient experiencing respiratory distress. These exercises help promote lung expansion, improve airway clearance, and relieve respiratory distress.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with impaired mobility?
options: Encouraging bed rest to conserve energy
Using restraints to prevent falls
Providing regular range-of-motion exercises
Limiting the patient's fluid intake
questions.explanation: Providing regular range-of-motion exercises is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with impaired mobility. These exercises help maintain joint mobility, prevent muscle atrophy, and improve circulation and overall physical health.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with a nasogastric (NG) tube?
options: Securing the NG tube to the patient's nose with adhesive tape
Irrigating the NG tube with cold water
Clamping the NG tube during feeding
Elevating the head of the bed during and after feeding
questions.answer: Elevating the head of the bed during and after feeding
questions.explanation: Elevating the head of the bed during and after feeding is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with a nasogastric (NG) tube. It helps prevent reflux and aspiration of gastric contents, promoting patient safety.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with a fever?
options: Applying cold compresses to the patient's forehead
Providing a warm blanket to the patient
Administering antipyretic medication as needed
Restricting fluid intake to prevent dehydration
questions.explanation: Administering antipyretic medication as needed is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with a fever. Antipyretic medications help reduce fever and alleviate discomfort.

questions.question:
Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with

 diarrhea?
options: Encouraging increased fluid intake
Restricting dietary fiber
Administering antidiarrheal medication without assessing bowel sounds
Encouraging the use of laxatives
questions.explanation: Encouraging increased fluid intake is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with diarrhea. Diarrhea can lead to fluid and electrolyte imbalances, and increasing fluid intake helps prevent dehydration.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with an acute myocardial infarction (MI)?
options: Encouraging bed rest to conserve energy
Administering a vasoconstrictor to increase blood pressure
Applying heat to the chest to relieve pain
Administering thrombolytic medication as ordered
questions.explanation: Administering thrombolytic medication as ordered is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with an acute myocardial infarction (MI). Thrombolytic medication helps dissolve blood clots and restore blood flow to the affected area, reducing myocardial damage.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with a stroke (cerebrovascular accident)?
options: Providing a soft diet to prevent choking
Administering a muscle relaxant to reduce muscle spasticity
Assisting with passive range-of-motion exercises
Administering anticoagulant medication without assessing coagulation profile
questions.explanation: Assisting with passive range-of-motion exercises is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with a stroke (cerebrovascular accident). These exercises help prevent muscle contractures, maintain joint mobility, and improve circulation.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with a urinary tract infection (UTI)?
options: Encouraging the use of bubble baths for perineal hygiene
Restricting fluid intake to reduce urine output
Administering diuretic medication without assessing urinary output
Encouraging increased fluid intake to promote urine flow
questions.answer: Encouraging increased fluid intake to promote urine flow
questions.explanation: Encouraging increased fluid intake to promote urine flow is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with a urinary tract infection (UTI). Adequate hydration helps flush out bacteria from the urinary system and promotes healing.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with diabetes mellitus?
options: Encouraging a high-carbohydrate diet
Administering insulin without checking blood glucose levels
Encouraging regular exercise and physical activity
Limiting fluid intake to prevent polyuria
questions.answer: Encouraging regular exercise and physical activity
questions.explanation: Encouraging regular exercise and physical activity is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with diabetes mellitus. Regular exercise helps control blood glucose levels, improves insulin sensitivity, and promotes overall health.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with a seizure disorder?
options: Restraining the patient during a seizure to prevent injury
Administering a stimulant to stop the seizure activity
Placing a padded tongue blade in the patient's mouth during a seizure
Ensuring a safe environment and removing any potentially hazardous objects
questions.answer: Ensuring a safe environment and removing any potentially hazardous objects
questions.explanation: Ensuring a safe environment and removing any potentially hazardous objects is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with a seizure disorder. It helps prevent injury during a seizure and promotes patient safety.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with acute pancreatitis?
options: Administering a high-fat diet to promote weight gain
Encouraging the patient to lie flat to relieve abdominal pain
Administering antacids to neutralize stomach acid
Providing pain relief and promoting rest
questions.answer: Providing pain relief and promoting rest
questions.explanation: Providing pain relief and promoting rest is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with acute pancreatitis. Resting the pancreas helps reduce inflammation and alleviate pain.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)?
options: Encouraging smoking cessation
Administering a bronchodilator without assessing lung sounds
Restricting fluid intake to prevent edema
Encouraging a high-sodium diet
questions.explanation: Encouraging smoking cessation is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Smoking cessation is the most effective way to slow the progression of COPD and improve lung function.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with heart failure?
options: Encouraging a high-sodium diet
Restricting fluid intake to prevent edema
Administering a diuretic without assessing fluid balance
Monitoring daily weights and assessing for signs of fluid overload
questions.answer: Monitoring daily weights and assessing for signs of fluid overload
questions.explanation:
Monitoring daily weights and assessing for signs of fluid overload is an appropriate nursing intervention for

 a patient with heart failure. These measures help evaluate fluid balance and identify early signs of worsening heart failure.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with a urinary catheter?
options: Securing the catheter with adhesive tape
Irrigating the catheter with normal saline every hour
Emptying the drainage bag when it is half full
Maintaining a dependent loop in the catheter tubing
questions.answer: Emptying the drainage bag when it is half full
questions.explanation: Emptying the drainage bag when it is half full is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with a urinary catheter. Regular emptying of the drainage bag helps prevent urinary stasis and infection.

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with a wound?
options: Applying direct pressure to control bleeding
Using sterile technique during wound dressing changes
Leaving the wound open to air
Applying heat to the wound to promote healing
questions.answer: Using sterile technique during wound dressing changes
questions.explanation: Using sterile technique during wound dressing changes is an appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with a wound. It helps prevent infection and promote wound healing.
